awd_titl_txt: Chemical Imaging of Elementary Steps in Hydrogenation Reactions of Surfaces
awd_abstract_narration:
With support from the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program in the Division of Chemistry, Professors Schwarz and Altman at Yale University are developing a new approach for the visualization and characterization of single molecule surface chemistry. This new approach is allowing the groups to control each step of a reaction using the tip of a scanning probe microscope where the specific and unique reaction pathway is chosen at will. Professors Schwarz and Altman are using this technique to study the interactions responsible to drive the reaction and to ultimately reveal the influence of nearby surface defects or other molecules.  The research outcomes are opening new venues to study surface chemistry and catalysis. Professors Schwarz and Altman are using carbon-hydrogen and carbon-carbon bond formation to illustrate the power of the technique. These bond formation reactions are fundamentally importantly and could have great impacts to the chemical and petrochemical industry. Professors Schwarz and Altman are using their research outcomes to reach out to the general public.

Professors Schwarz and Altman are developing a high-resolution tool to locally map energy landscape between an adsorbed molecule and the surface underneath, with the aims of quantifying energy minima for specific chemical bond formation or dissociation and subsequently manipulating single molecule surface chemistry at will.  Specifically, they are (1) further developing their atomic force microscopy technique to quantify the interaction between the tip and a sample, and map potential, forces, and currents in three dimensions; (2) using the developed technique to study adsorption of aromatic molecules and hydrogen, and manipulate their chemical behaviors; and (3) testing the technique with local creation of benzyl radicals and formation of associated products.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Advances in scanning probe microscopy have made it possible to not only image molecules on surfaces, but also to map the entire surface potential around the molecule, thereby uncovering sites of enhanced local reactivity; translate atoms and molecules while measuring the diffusion barrier between potential minima, thereby detecting these barriers as a function of the specific lattice site and of the chemical environment; and finally split molecules (dissociation) using energy provided by the tip of the scanning probe microscope. The intellectual merit of this proposal has been to combine these three elements to achieve a qualitative and quantitative picture of the initial elementary steps involved in surface reactions, delivering information not available through other means, thereby aiding the development of novel computational approaches.

 

Towards this end, the following four major activities were carried out: (1) We used the model system of benzene on copper (100) to obtain insight into the breadth of possible outcomes for on-surface manipulation using the microscope’s tip as a tool and then be able to classify the observed outcomes. The results indicate that there were five categories of outcomes: The molecules were either (i) pushed by the approaching tip in the direction of the tip motion; (ii) pulled towards the tip when it was approaching; (iii) dragged along the tip trajectory when the tip was behind or almost behind the molecule; (iv) jumped to the tip, which looked like they suddenly “disappeared” from the surface, or (v) did not move depending on the chemical surroundings of the molecules and the chemical identity of the tip. While we were able to determine the energy barriers between potential minima from the data obtained, we found that these barriers were reduced as the tip “pulls the molecule up”, which aids the molecular motion. (2) To get further insight into the molecular-level interactions that govern the observed effects, we compared the experimentally obtained energy landscapes and barrier heights with computational results. Towards this end, we have combined atomistic simulations with Bayesian optimization, an artificial intelligence (AI) technique designed for complicated optimization tasks. Energy and force landscapes can then be data-mined to obtain the minimum energy paths a molecule that is transferred from one potential minimum to another. The results suggest that, as expected, the presence of the tip lowers the energy barrier the molecule has to overcome during its motion, which evolves with the chemical identity of the tip. (3) Moving on from the benzene-on-copper system, we modified to use iodobenzene instead. This system has the advantage that it allows to easily produce phenyl groups by splitting off the iodine atom from the benzene ring through local pulsing with the tip; this leads to the formation of a C-Cu bond that couples the phenyl tighter to the substrate, thereby lessening the influence of the tip. As a consequence, we observed markedly different jump distances and barriers. (4) To uncover the origin of the phenyl’s observed motion on the copper surface, we performed density functional theory calculations, which revealed that due to the relatively tight bond of the phenyl radical with the surface, molecular motions that are vastly distinct from the ones found for the benzene are enabled. Most importantly, the phenyl radicals feature rotation and flipping around the C-Cu, with these motions likely explaining the different jump distances and barriers that were experimentally observed.

 

The broader impact of the work is that we have obtained a detailed understanding of how tip-molecule and molecule-substrate interactions influence the results of the manipulation, which also led to the identification of steps that will improve the applied approaches for future experimentation. This can result in a more accurate quantitative measurement of the resulting lateral forces the molecule needs to overcome during surface diffusion. Building on these advances, a reliable methodology where surface reactions can be induced by the tip of a scanning probe microscope and the reaction pathway is chosen at will could be in reach, which would enable an individualized, site-specific understanding of single-molecule surface chemistry. The project also provided student and postdoc training opportunities in high-resolution scanning probe microscopy measurements, sample preparation, low temperature and ultrahigh vacuum techniques, and surface spectroscopies while also providing them with deep theoretical insight into surface chemistry and surface reactions. Finally, through its ability to “visualize chemistry”, results from this work also supported outreach activities for the public.
